repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: Currently comment detection, addition, and removal are done
  by matching 'commentstring' exactly. This has the downside when users
  want to add comment markers with space (like with `-- %s`
  commentstring) but also be able to uncomment lines that do not contain
  space (like `--aaa`).

Solution: Use the following approach:
  - Line is commented if it matches 'commentstring' with trimmed parts.
  - Adding comment is 100% relying on 'commentstring' parts (as is now).
  - Removing comment is first trying exact 'commentstring' parts with fallback on trying its trimmed parts.

------

Resolve #28872

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
Matching 'commentstring' does not account for whitespace in comment markers when uncommenting.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -579,6 +579,10 @@ Acting on multiple lines behaves as follows:
   transformed to empty comments (e.g. `/**/`). Comment markers are aligned to
   the least indented line.
 
+Matching 'commentstring' does not account for whitespace in comment markers.

comment_data.body: Matching 'commentstring' is about deciding what action should be done: commenting or uncommenting. So I don't think it is a good idea to add this detail.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -579,6 +579,10 @@ Acting on multiple lines behaves as follows:
   transformed to empty comments (e.g. `/**/`). Comment markers are aligned to
   the least indented line.
 
+Matching 'commentstring' does not account for whitespace in comment markers.

comment_regular_data.body: How does this work with _leading_ whitespace in `'cms'` (e.g., COBOL)?

> How does this work with _leading_ whitespace in `'cms'` (e.g., COBOL)?

I thought it was a joke, because there is no 'commentstring' in 'cobol.vim' and I did not understand that it was about leading spaces.

I believe the reason it has no set 'commentstring' is because `setlocal commentstring=\ \ \ \ \ \ *%s` will match any `*` in at least column 7, while the proper way seems to be `*` *exactly* in column 7. This also does not work with adding comment, as it will insert `      *` to any line (and again, not make `*` appear in column 7).

Right now it will correctly uncomment the correctly commented line. For lines like `  *` this PR will remove only asterisk while current behavior will add `      *`.

So all in all, I don't think this will work for COBOL.
If the previous behavior didn't work (reliably) for that case either, then this is no objection.

> If the previous behavior didn't work (reliably) for that case either, then this is no objection.

Both current and this PR's behaviors work with 'commentstring' which has whitespace "outside" of comment parts (to the left of left part and to the right of right part). It is [tested](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/5ac8db10f0428c976dfc9a4935a74d0fe160995c/test/functional/lua/comment_spec.lua#L182-L229).

It works in a sense that that whitespace is included in comment markers: adding comment adds markers with that whitespace, matching is done with trimmed markers (after this PR), and uncommenting (after this PR) first tries with that whitespace and then falls back without that whitespace. The logic is that any whitespace in commentstring is trimmed in fallback: line `--aaa` should be uncommented even with `  --  %s` commentstring. This is the core of the issue. I've added an extra test case for " /*%s*/ " commentstring to have this tested.

Now, when it comes to comment structure of COBOL specifically ("A comment line is any line with an asterisk (*) or slash (/) in the indicator area (column 7) of the line"), then it indeed doesn't work now for 100% of cases with `      *%s` commentstring:
- It works if line is properly commented (starts with `      *`) or not commented (starts at column 1). After this PR it will continue to work.
- It does not work otherwise. Adding comment does not ensure that line starts with `      *` but only adds this prefix at first non-blank column. After this PR it will continue to not work.

Great!

Maybe for a follow-up PR, could we also use `vim.opt.comments` for uncommenting?
If you can understand it, be our guest!

> Great!
> 
> Maybe for a follow-up PR, could we also use `vim.opt.comments` for uncommenting?

I am more inclined to not have it used for uncommenting. Here is the copy of my reasoning from target issue:

> The most proper solution would be to have a separate options for "comment structure for adding comment" and "comment regex to match commented line", but there is no such thing. The closest is 'comments' option but it is more about how to place proper prefixes during editing (like after `<CR>`, `O`, `J`, etc.). It is also quite popularly used to define bulleted lists and has somewhat complicated set of flags to implement.

My guess would be that this subfeature alone would increase module LoC count by at least 50%. Together with its "not exactly comments" usage, I'd not rely on it.

A separate dedicated option ('uncommentlist' maybe?) might be a better solution.

Seems to be indeed quite complex :)

But this is all we need I think:

> When a string has none of the 'f', 's', 'm' or 'e' flags, Vim assumes the
comment string repeats at the start of each line.  The flags field may be
empty.

So this should give a list of comment strings we can use for uncommenting:

```lua
local css = vim.tbl_filter(
  function(str)
    return str ~= false
  end,
  vim.tbl_map(function(cs)
    local flags, str = cs:match("^(.-):(.*)$")
    return flags and not flags:match("[fsme]") and str or false
  end, vim.opt.comments:get())
)
```

> So this should give a list of comment strings we can use for uncommenting

Which would itself increase complexity of current code designed only for a single source of comment markers.

title: fix(comment): fall back to using trimmed comment markers
